chapter.title: Validating input fields
chapter.para: An input field often represents a data type that's not just a boring, plain text string. An input field, for example, may prompt for an integer that should be an int. It becomes necessary to take the free-form text entered into the input field and parse it into an int.

A validated input field is an input field whose entered text gets validated and stored in a std::optional<type>. The type might be an int or some other data type that represents the entered text. The entered text gets successfully validated and converted to the type, and stored into the std:optional. A std::nullopt std:optional indicates that no value is yet entered in the input field, or the entered text cannot be converted into the type.

set_validator() and set_string_validator() install &callback;s that get executed to validate the input field's text and convert it to some arbitrary type. They take two closures, or callable objects, as parameters. The first closure takes the input field's contents and returns the std::optional<type> representing the validated value. set_validator() and set_string_validator() return an &ns;::w::validated_input_field<type>. This object represents the most recently validated value.

note.para: The closure returns a std::optional without a value to indicate that the entered text is not valid. The closure gets called when leaving the input field. Returning a value-less std::optional results in the input focus staying in the input field, but no other visible action. An appropriate error message should appear somewhere to provide usable feedback, to clearly indicate that the entered input is not valid.

The closure's first parameter is a std::string or a std::u32string containing the entered text, and the escond parameter is its own &ns;::w::input_field object. validatedinput.C shows a simple example of using its stop_message() method, which display a modal dialog with a stop icon, and an error message.

chapter.para: The second parameter to set_validator() and set_string_validator() is another closure, or a callable object, that takes a std::optional<type> and converts it to some standardized, or canonical, format, returning it as a std::string or a std::u32string which replaces the typed-in text, if it differs from the canonical format.

note.para: The second closure is not a IN_THREAD callback. &ns;::w::validated_input_field<type> offers a set() method that sents the input field to a type value. This uses the second closure to format the value into a text string, so that the closure may not necessarily be callable ONLY IN_THREAD.

chapter.para: Date input fields use this to allow only a month and a day to be typed into the date input field, which gets supplemented by the default year. Input field validation occurs when tabbing out of the date input field, or clicking outside of it with the pointer button. The typed in text gets replaced by its canonical format that includes the year.

section.title: Using on_validate()
section.para: set_validator() and set_string_validator() implement their validation logic using on_validate(), which installs a &callback; that gets invoked by enter Enter, or by attempting to tab out of the text input field. on_validate() is a low-level &callback;; set_validator() and set_string_validator() add their own supplemental logic to retrieve the text input's contents, and validate it according to their rules.
An additional use case for on_validate() is in conjunction with the item layout manager.
